I don't know.

How did you get my...
My God!

I'll do this! You
stay there. Stay there!

comments.text:
Ok. Bourne series are great but those fights are absolutely and completely 
unrealistic. I realize that fights in  Chinese action movies are more 
unrealistic than that, but it's still unbearable for anyone who's knows one 
thing about street fight, or had any experience with martial arts, or 
watched any UFC fight, or whatever. But this is really, really bad. The 
weakest point of the movie if we talk about realism. But I guess it will do 
for someone who doesn't know a thing about fighting﻿

moves which takes skill

comments.author: RYSE

comments.text:
No they didn't neglect it. They thought it sounded good. That's why all the 
movies from back then sounded like that. That's my whole point.
comments.author: RYSE

comments.text:
+RYSE "They wouldn't have neglected that."

But they did neglect it, so...
comments.author: degree7

comments.text: Yeah that's true! That's probably why nobody noticed it :p
comments.author: RYSE

comments.text:
I mean, sound effects back then were just campy like this. Watch any action 
movie before 2005
comments.author: frank ponds

comments.text:
That's what foley is. Sounds added in post production. An believe me punch 
sound effects are one of the most important things in the movie. They 
wouldn't have neglected that. The whole reason I commented was because I 
never remembered the bad sound effects in such a great movie. I never said 
I would have been able to do it better but I'm not the only one who noticed 
it so I don't know why you're so hostile.
comments.author: RYSE

comments.text:
Punch sound effects were probably added in during post production, or 
editing. Usually filmmakers are on a tight schedule, corners had to be cut, 
details left out. I'm sure they could have taken a sound technician to a 
warehouse and recorded people punching bags of meat, but they probably 
didn't have time. It's too bad you weren't there to point out the obvious 
flaw to the director, you could have improved the movie so much.
comments.author: degree7

comments.text:
+degree7 No need for sarcasm man. And if a movie centred around action 
sequences needs to watch their budget, i don't think punch sounds will be 
the first think they'll cut down on. Good foley doesn't cost that much.
comments.author: RYSE

comments.text:
+RYSE News flash: movies are made on limited budgets, and sometimes 
sacrifices have to be made.
comments.author: degree7

comments.text: Yes they are, but it could be worse.

comments.text:
Ever since I first saw this scene, I was obsessed with learning krav maga 
or eskrima, but then I realized that taking those classes is useless 
because I would never be able to use these techniques in real life 
situations without ever practicing them in real life scenario. Like Bruce 
Lee said, can't learn to swim by staying on dry land. You might be able to 
take a gun from the opponents hand in a class but doing it in a street from 
a real thief is a whole other story. That's why I decided to learn boxing 
instead, it's simple and I get to do actual sparring which allows me to 
learn the whole depth of this sport instead of just practicing punches﻿

most efficient at MMA, but training is gruesome, stick with judo, jiu jitsu 
or aikido, which I think is best for defense!

comments.author: Steve Garrod

comments.text:
Matt Damon created in Jason Bourne a great character. This is a man who is 
lost. He has no memory. He doesn't know much about himself but as the movie 
continued he soon began to learn things about himself. The Government need 
him dead before he works it all about and this their first attempt. When 
this guy crashes through the window Bourne leaps into action. He has a 
friend in Marie and he has to defend her against this guy. Its a great 
fight scene. Bourne was great because he used things around him in a fight. 
Any item he could get his hands on could be useful. He stabs this guy with 
a pen! Brilliant stuff! Great action movie!﻿
comments.author: shanemental

comments.text:
I always get irritated because their moves are too fast for a normal speed 
camera... they  could have used a high-speed one, unless technology like 
that didn't exist back then? It would be so much more enjoyable than the 
blurred fight movments.﻿
comments.author: avelione

comments.text: +Clarence Baluca Well, ok. I believe you. Good for ya, I guess ;)
comments.author: avelione

comments.text:
+avelione I'm a martial artist and former assistant instructor. I 
specialize in Kali. Yes. Just like Bourne, and I can tell that the average 
fighter moves much faster than this. Watch the fights in the other three 
Bourne films. That is how fast fights really go, if you are on the same 
skill level as a highly-trained CIA assassin. I may not be a CIA assassin 
but even with the little training I have I still move just as fast. What 
you see in those street fight videos are mostly unskilled.
comments.author: Clarence Baluca

comments.text:
+Clarence Baluca I've seen some street fight on YT and it doesn't seem that 
much faster... but I'm no expert. And how do you know? :D Still, a 
high-speed camera like in "Winter Soldier" would make the figh scenes much 
more awesome looking.
comments.author: avelione

comments.text: +avelione It's still really slow compared to a real fight though... :/

comments.author: Zeemas

comments.text: Those punching sounds are just sooo ridiculously over the top.﻿
comments.author: brazenblaze

comments.text: what a total James Bond ripoff﻿
comments.author: TheGore1021

comments.text:
+Mitchell Olson The reason I thought this is a Bond ripoff is because the 
way how the action begins: A guy ambushes by breaking through the window 
and start going after Bourne as a mission to kill him.

1. Yes, Daniel Craig loses his love of his life, just like what happened in 
the old Bond movies, where Bond was getting married to a women and he loses 
his wife by getting killed.

2. In Skyfall, Bond was shot off a train, and was falsely dead. They used 
the element that was used in one of the old Bond plots, as "You Only Live 
Twice". When Bond was falsely dead, he doesn't pass the tests, because he 
lost some of his strength in himself for only just a bit, because he was 
too banged up. It was just like how Bond was in the old Bond plots

Even tho, when I said this is a Bond ripoff, then my guess is, I'm having a 
mistake saying it. Because characters have there own development and 
stories, and you are right.
comments.author: TheGore1021

comments.text:
+TheGore1021 So might I ask again, how is this a Bond ripoff? And I'm not 
saying Bond is a ripoff of Bourne, but the new movies certainly took a 
thing or two away form Bourne.

1. Daniel Craig loses the love of his life, the women he was gonna settle 
down with, just like Bourne. He goes through emotional pain and inner 
torment for a sequence, just like Bourne.

2. In skyfall, Bourne is betrayed and left behind by his agency and is 
forced to go rouge and act along for once. This again, is just like Bourne.

You may say, that's only two things. However, those two things play major 
roles in the character development and the story.
comments.author: Mitchell Olson

comments.text:
+Mitchell Olson Of course, and you are right. Because every spy movie has 
different stuff with there own stories and characteristics. But, what's 
mostly stupid is that people say that the new Bond is a Bourne ripoff. And 
they are completely wrong, because the story/plot is not the same at all, 
and they are nothing like the Bourne movies at all
comments.author: TheGore1021

comments.text:
+TheGore1021 So can anyone make another spy movie without it being a Bond 
ripoff? Bonds story is much different as well. Not even close to being the 
same story/plot.
comments.author: Mitchell Olson

comments.text: So can anyone make another spy movie without it being a Bond ripoff?
comments.author: Mitchell Olson

comments.text:
+Mitchell Olson Because he's been on for years. But in some of the films, 
he had more than one other characteristic that was in his portrayal. In 
action, he's been ambushed in his homes before by bad guys because they 
were sent to kill him, and he's killed bad guys in hand to hand fights, and 
he ran away from guys who were after him.
comments.author: TheGore1021

comments.text:
+TheGore1021 Bond is way too hollywood. Might I add it's the same thing 
over 22 films? Sleeping with women, sucking down martinis, and killing 
people.

them multiple times, dont remember it ever saying/implying that he knew 
bourne was also an assassin] might figure a MP5 is more then enough to get 
the job done...  Do you not realize what an mp5 is capable of?  Should he 
have brought a nuke?

comments.author: INFILTR8US

comments.text:
This is the 2nd best fight from the entire Bourne franchise, where the 
viewer can see his full potential for the 1st time. Before he had been 
already beating up some policemen & security guards, but he mostly caught 
them by surprise. Now it's against a trained assassin, and he's a match 
even for this one. I was in cinema, my jaw dropped & i couldn't believe my 
eyes. Such a cool scene, totally unexpected. 
The best fight I think is Bourne vs. Desh. Desh being younger, larger & 
stronger, and Bourne could still overpower him. There you could really see 
Bourne's quality & experience. 
I wish they'd do some more movies (with Damon). ﻿
comments.author: harpyion

face, elbows and fists, and he's still active.

comments.author: jjtech

comments.text:
You lost me at Seagal.  Entertainment is simply entertainment, no matter 
how well it is researched. I appreciate the impressive think tank Spielberg 
got together for the minority report, but the end result is fiction.  It's 
meant to entertain.  It's not a documentary.  To look for more meaning than 
that in it is a waste of time for me.  That's what your front door is for, 
to explore the real world.  Seagal fights are no more 'realistic' or 
technically proficient than bourne fights. They are designed to look great 
on the big screen.  As you said, most 'real' fights are over in seconds, 
but wouldn't that be a terrible let down if you plunk down cash to go see 
the equalizer, which also had some nice unrealistic fight sequences :)
comments.author: busywl69

comments.text:
+busywl69 Nonsense. Scorsese did realistic movies portraying life of mafia. 
This is what good movies are about. Just like whole series of Sopranos were 
extremely realistic. Including how FBI operated Why? Because people who 
made those movies did their homework and bothered to hire people who knew 
how it was. Nicholas Pileggi was a journalist who wrote about Mafia and 
knew how they worked inside-out. This is why DeNiro, Pesci and Liotta 
"often spoke with Pileggi, who shared research material left over from 
writing the book". Why? To REALISTICALLY portray the behavior of a memeber 
of outfit. This is also why DeNiro before the "Raging Bull" started 
training boxing - to look REALISTIC as a boxer. And he did. Realistic movie 
made in HOLLYWOOD. Just as Casino: Heat, Insider (M. Mann); Wolf of 
Wallstreet - in most of those movies you had bits and pieces of how the CIA 
worked. We're talking about fights, not how the CIA works - any Steven 
Seagal movie have more realistic fight sequences than what they did in 
Bourne. It's simply a botched job, nothing else. It could have been done 
better. To summarize - I don't have a problem with Greengrass' portrayal of 
CIA and other intellgence agencies, such as MI% work - it's pretty much 
exact with what we know from whistleblowers (such as Ann Machon for 
example). He also showed citizen invigilation in the US and Europe - again, 
very accurate and even a bit "prophetic" as we didn't have Snowden 
revelations back than and a lot of delusional film critics accused 
Greengrass of "cospiracy theories".
comments.author: jjtech

comments.text:
I would have joined the CIA if I wanted that kind of realism, your not 
going to get it in a Hollywood movie.  Ever.
comments.author: busywl69

comments.text:
+busywl69
That's exactly right. There are realistic fiction movies, in a way that 
laws of physics, human psychological reactions, dialogue are portrayed in a 
realistic way. this is for example why "From Here To Eterninty" is a very 
realistic novel about the WWII, and "Heat" by Michael Mann is a realistic 
fiction movie. Just as "Deer Hunter" is. Bourne series is much more 
realistic than say James Bond, which is a total garbage in every aspect of 
portaying reality. But you might be better off watching some donald duck 
and mickey mouse.
comments.author: jjtech

comments.author: Clarence Baluca

comments.text:
+gtnash LOL... keysi fighting method is a scam.... most of those techniques 
of keysi were influences from Filipino martial art.... they were students 
of Filipino martial art under JKD.... those techniques of Jason Bourne like 
using pen, book, towel as weapons are all concepts from Filipino martial 
art... in Kali Eskrima, everything is a weapon.... you see this even in 
James Bond film like James Bond grabbing a pen and killing his opponent in 
"Quantum of Solace" movie....
comments.author: Topherodesk

comments.text:
+Topherodesk You are correct that Bourne movies extensively use FMA, 
especially panantukan/dirty boxing.

I mispoke by including the Bourne Trilogy in the list of KFM films. 
 However, being rude by snidely typing "everybody knows that, just search 
google" was unnecessary and not constructive.
comments.author: gtnash

comments.text:
+gtnash Bourne movies use Filipino martial art Kali Eskrima..... everybody 
knows that just search google....
comments.author: Topherodesk

comments.text:
Yes.  It's called KFM (Keysi Fighting Method) and is featured in
The Dark Knight Trilogy, the Bond Trilogy, the Bourne movies, Jack Reacher, 
& Oblivion to just name a few.
The style relies heavily on fluid Forearm-Shield blocking, Elbow Strikes & 
Hammer-Fists.
